YouTube™ Video: Indiebitably - Destiny Warriors: More than likely a scam, definitely a ripoff of Naruto. 

			Views: 1,130		

			I review the game Destiny Warriors and detail some of the very suspicious activities around it and its developers. Original review on...		

Not a well made game at all, a user called HappyPanda calling themself a "game promotion company" was handing out free copies of the game code and telling people that they are influential members of the community and would love it if a review was left (edit: somebody accused me of making this review because I was salty I didn't get a code, I was actually one of the people he sent a review code to and I am clearly in no way an influential member of the gaming community and you have never heard of me unless you've killed me repeatedly on another videogame) and that they would be handing out copies of a game called Road Redemption next week. This same "company" has left a positive of the review after logging 0.1 hours, basically playing long enough so that steam would allow them to leave a positive review (edit: HappyPanda has mysteriously decided to actually log time into the game after this review came out, almost as if he now realizes having a positive review with between 0-6 minutes played is a dumb move). The review also says "Seems to be well worth the price so far" worth what price? He's the "game promotion company" handing out free copies of the game so he clearly didn't pay any money for it. The same people that are handing out review copies leaving a positive review is sketchy at best, it seems like a ploy to get positive reviews in at the start to scam people into buying the game. Edit: The user HappyPanda is confirmed to be a dev for Road Redemption (the game they are handing out codes for next week), whether they are a dev for Destiny Warriors I am unsure of but the the fact that they are hiding that they are devs when reaching out to people and calling themselves a "game promotion company" just makes it all that sketchier. Onto the game itself: Not good. Storyline: Lazy ripoff of Naruto with cringy dialogue and a ridiculous amount of grammatical errors. In one of the first scenes, you meet one of the characters named Kitt his own name is mispelled everytime he talks while everyone else says it properly, this no longer happens in later scenes, there are constant grammatical issues and entire words missing from the dialogue. The actual story: There is a Kage of the Grass village who sealed rampant beasts inside children (sound familiar? keep reading). Your main character is a slacker/klutz type put in a squad with someone classed as a "bookworm" despite him clearly being the strongest and macho-esque one in the squad. There is a girl healer and a male who is LITERALLY classed as "The Emo" just so they can have the Sakura-Sasuke relationship thing going on. The first mission as a squad? You must collect a bunch of bells your squad leader has hidden...bells. You could literally be finding ANYTHING but they couldn't be arsed to even change it to something besides bells. Gameplay: Not good, abilities have little or no animations that make no sense to them at all. A "clone x-tu" (jutsu but they clearly couldn't even bother to find a new name for it so they just wrote X-tu) is literally just your character walking up to the enemy and attacking it, there is no clone of any sort. A fireball is just a random burst of fire where the enemy is standing. They haven't even programmed in the ability to choose 2 targets on abilities so your 2 target abilities hit random targets, sometimes targets that aren't even alive anymore. Enemies do little to no damage and spend half their turns defending and just dragging the battle out, one mob does about 20 damage when it attacks yet when it poisons a character they take 100+ damage a turn. Oh yeah, your characters start out with an absurd amount of health and level up at an insane rate despite killing the exact same weak enemies. Your main character does around 100 damage with his standard attack, the enemies you encounter at the start have about that much health. The kicker? Your characters do not actually have any weapons equipped when you get them, not even a basic rusty sword or anything which is just plain lazy and makes me wonder what in the hell are they infusing when they use weapon enhancement abilities? The majority of the ablities are lazy renamings (your non-clone clone jutsu also has thunder clone, fire clone, etc. variations) and have animations that don't match them at all. Based on the clips provided on the steam page it appears that even later in the game the damage values barely change if at all.  Overall Impression: Not worth the time, I quit after 40-something minutes because of how bad it was and I was trying to push myself to give an accurate review. Hell, if you really want to try it go contact HappyPanda he'll probably give you a free copy if you say you'll give it a good review.

												In a fantasy world, in order to prevent the dark forces from destroying it, students are taught in numerous combat methods and become ninjas. The story focuses on the four main player characters, who share some rather humorous interactions during the course of their adventure to destroy the numerous bosses (I know its a generic term, but thats basically what they are) to protect the land. Anyway, summary over, on to the review!This game is enjoyable, I will be finishing this game. So, you may be wondering why I am giving this a negative review. Personally, I do not think the game, in it's current state, is publishing worthy. I am not just saying this because it is a RPG Maker Game, I actually am adept at using RPG Maker and applaud the creators of this game for attempting to publish it. So I have some words of advice for the creators of this game. If you are going to post a RPG Maker Game, unless it has custom materials, forget about it. The major let down for me during my playing time is the lack of unique, custom assets. Anyone that has either played to many RPG Maker Games or has used the program itself will not find the use of default materials exciting. I liked the comical aspects of the story and characters, but when compared to other similar games, it is still lacking. I know how hard it is to make a game that can be competitive in this market, but I have high hopes that with some changes, this game could become something. Having created numerous RPG Maker games (none of which I have published/monitized), I know the efforts that go into making one of a large scale. So, to review what I have said concerning what this game needs...-Custom Material is the most important thing. Using a example map with a few small changes isn't going to make it. Also, although sound doesn't seem all to important, the right sounds can make or brake a game. Although some of the sounds work, I would suggest changing up a little for variety.There are some things that I did find interesting, and think is a job well done...-Menus. The menus were actually very nice, well edited and so on. Some of the menu designs look similar/exact to some that I have found online, which is fine, as long as you have recieved proper permissions to use them (if applicable).-Combat system, although not overally so impressed. The combat is a basic sideview battler system, so that does seperate it from the typical first person battle view. Might I ask though, did you create the battle system yourselves, or did you use one of the common online scripts such as Yanfly's Battle System (I hope I named it right, I haven't used RPG Maker in a while, so I have forgotten a lot of the script providers names).In short, the game is not of the level where I think it should be monitized. I have personally created games that are on par or better than this one (based on unique materials, custom scripts, so on), and even those I would not feel confident enough about to publish commercially. I do intend to beat this game, and will most likely enjoy doing so, but overall I cannot approve of this game. I applaud the developers on their work, but this game is just lacks the uniqueness that games like this desperately need.May your adventures be many and always end in reward!-Donoknight, Guildmaster of the Tabletop RPG Gamers LeagueNote to the Developers: If you have any questions concerning my review or need any help concerning the future plans/changes to this game, I am happy to help in whatever way I can to help this game thrive in this competitive market.

Review - Destiny Warriors RPG"A Naruto-inspired game that features game elements from Dragon Quest and Pokemon."Destiny Warriors RPG is a turn-based Adventure RPG game made from RPG Maker. It's a Naruto-inspired game mixed with Dragon Quest and Pokemon concepts. I'm quite a fan of RPG Maker games but this one disappointed me the most for quite a lot of reasons. Pros:+ The graphics are okay+ The game is quite cheap+ Has trading cardsCons:- Dialogues have a lot of typos.- The story/plot is terrible. (The story is a naruto rip-off)- Dungeons are poorly-made leading to a very repetitive gameplay. It takes out the player's interest to explore the world (should stick to only one style of dungeon design either random monster encounter or placing actual monsters on the field)- Bad level up system. (Some characters will be used at the latter part of the game and you get to use them at level 5 when all of your characters are already level 10+. Max also gets stuck at level 15.)- Battle System is not balanced. (All your characters have high HP but their attacks just won't get strong. The enemies' HP gets higher but their attacks also don't get stronger at all. Having a higher level only shows that you have high HP and MP)It's hard to make a decent game from RPG Maker that would actually sell because of the lack resources, etc. This game has a lot of potential but seeing the story is nearly similar to Naruto, it actually blew out the whole experience for me. It doesn't mean that if you change some of the terms, it's already a different game especially if it was based on a very well-known game/anime such as Naruto. It's not easy to make a nice and interesting story especially for a game.Anyway, I don't recommend this game to gamers who have played quite a lot of RPG Maker-made games but if you're a Naruto fan and you don't mind a somewhat retelling of the Naruto story under different names, then you can try this game since it's quite cheap.Personal Rating:Gameplay: 5/10 (very repetitive)Story: 4/10 (Nearly same plot as Naruto with a slight few modifications)Music: 6/10 Graphics: 6/10Overall: 5/10

And yes, for some fire attacks they get very little damage. But for a few fire attacks, they receive the same damage as others, and can also suffer from the "+burn" status effect - even though the graphics clearly depict them as being already on fire (and their element is fire)! Where's the logic?!3) At the ninja tournament, you are suddenly made to use characters you were not using on a regular basis before. (The game always forcefully assigns characters to you to fight with throughout.) As a result, because these characters were not prepped or appropriately levelled up for the challenge, it is nigh impossible to win the battle using them. You have to be popping +HP pills all the time, and even then it's a huge challenge (you just have to betting on the fact that your opponent won't kill you using one of their specials, which have the potential to wipe you out at one go, since your opponents are several levels higher than you are, and equipped with the best possible gear!!!). Where's the fun in that???4) Normal attacks, which consume no MP and TP, deal WAY more damage than magic/skill attacks. I'm talking figures like 448 (using normal attack) as opposed to 92 (using MP/TP attack). Get lost!!!!!!5) You never ever get a chance to remove status effects like +poison, +blind, +burn, etc because some of your enemies are so fast that their turn keeps coming before you even get a chance to move. This in particular happens during the ninja tournament. So, just wait to die. Kthx.I suspect most of the these problems have to do with the fact that, after you reach a certain level, the game just suddenly starts assigning you enemies that are at least 2-3 levels higher than you. So when you're at level 27 for instance, you could be facing 6 enemies at levels 28, 27, 29, 29, 25, 28 respectively. And yes, it's YOU (one person), versus 6 of them. What the hell.It's a pity because I kind of enjoyed the game in the earlier stages, before it started going completely insane with the battle system. The story was corny, but the narrative and goals were clear, and there were many places and items to explore. (Speaking of which, some of the items were bleedin' USELESS. Once again, you'll only find this out later on in the game when more items start becoming available, and you realise they are 100% redundant. You can't even use many of them during battle. Shan't elaborate because my consternation at this game is growing with every word I type.)So, yeah. I basically wasted my time going this far in this game, because I've concluded that it's impossible to proceed without some extreme hair-tearing and head-banging (against the wall or table) due to the anger and frustration that this game's battle system will induce in you.I should also mention that the English is beyond atrocious. E.g. "insensitive" used instead of "incentive"; "peak" used instead of "pique", and so on. And you get spellings like "rouge" (instead of "rogue" - and the wrongly-spelled version appears for the WHOLE game!!!), "paralized" (instead of "paralysed"), etc etc. Very often, the words are spelled like how the game author thinks they are pronounced, instead of what they actually are. He could probably write his own dictionary with the sheer number of words he's re-spelled. And then there's the dialogue - in the beginning of the game it's still quite ok, then suddenly, you start seeing "f***" appear everywhere.*shakes head*Forget it. Just forget it.

I know that RPG maker stories tend to have these cliche stories about defeating evil, collecting crystals, killing the four overlords of whatever and whatnot. Even great game series like Final Fantasy did that so you normally are supposed to turn a blind eye and give the game a chance regardless, but I don't even want to give it the benefit of the doubt because the writing is just that bad right off the bat. Nope, it's your typical Final Fantasy like combat. While that's not bad, it certainly isn't innovative, either. Now RPG Maker games seldom want to be innovative, but they kind of have to be if the story and characters fail to deliver. 												Destiny Warriors is a RPG Maker made game whose whole premise is taken almost verbatim off of the manga Naruto, even titles, characters, and events are basically the same. Storyline is bland and the use of vulgarity takes you back to when you were in middle school and started cursing for the first time. Generic, unoriginal soundtrack with a flood of grammatical errors help to unimmerse you from what would be a terrible game to an unplayable game. Battle system is riddled with tediousness and unbalanced scaling, just plain boring with a lot of glitches (ex: where the tooltip for certain abilities would let you attack multiple enemies and only give you one attack). Everytime I tried to take a screenshot or close the game it crashed by itself.Battle System:Enemies do little to no damage and spend half their turns defending and just dragging the battle out, one mob does about 20 damage when it attacks yet when it poisons a character they take 100+ damage a turn. Oh yeah, your characters start out with an absurd amount of health and level up at an insane rate despite killing the exact same weak enemies. Your main character does around 100 damage with his standard attack, the enemies you encounter at the start have about that much health. The kicker? Your characters do not actually have any weapons equipped when you get them, not even a basic rusty sword or anything which is just plain lazy and makes me wonder what in the hell are they infusing when they use weapon enhancement abilities? The majority of the ablities are lazy renamings (your non-clone clone jutsu also has thunder clone, fire clone, etc. variations) and have animations that don't match them at all. Based on the clips provided on the steam page it appears that even later in the game the damage values barely change if at all. Pros:+ If you don't know anything about Naruto then you might have some funCons:- Storyline is a bland blatant rip off of one of the more popular manga's (Naruto)- Generic Soundtrack straight from RPG Maker- Battle system is boring and unbalanced- Dialogue is extremely poor and vulgar and full of grammatical errors that create and unimmersive experience- Littered with glitchesTL;DR:2/10I always strive to give games a chance, even the indie developers and the RPG Maker games that playeres produce, but this is among the few games you should avoid even if it's a few dollars.

												So, here we have Destiny Warriors RPG, "heavily influenced by Chrono Trigger, Final Fantasy and the Dragon Quest series". Those are some big names. So how heavy is this game influenced be the aforementioned titles? Not much. I - being a lover especially of Chrono Trigger - didn't even see a hint about it except that both games are basically in a classic RPG-Style.What did I like?-The beginning wasn't exceptional but ok.-The game itself works - most of the time.-I really did want to see how the story progresses and it all ends. But it seems I can't drag myself through the end. It's just too painful.-I liked the idea of implementing quizzes regarding the games setting for getting some additional items and one part of the storyline.-Some thought and work has been invested into it.What did I dislike? Oh boy, actually a ton...-All the assets are as far as I can tell stock assets, which does not need to be a huge downside. But be warned: you might've seen these faces and animations in a lot of games, you've heard the songs thousands of times, the sounds are old friends (which might be a plus if you're very into it)...-At the beginning, it plays pretty smooth, your characters learn new abilities, they progress through levels and get stronger. However, soon leveling is almost obsolete. Enemies will then always take lower damage and dish out more than your characters can. The only attacks which work good are so Chi-expensive you need to carry ludicrous amounts of Chi-pills with you; and healing kits or "tents" (which revive all of your crew). "Elemental attacks" aren't really that powerful even against the correct "contra-element". Gear does more for winning a battle than leveling. Luck DECIDES MOST OF YOUR BATTLES. Even if your "gang" has the highest possible levels (it is 50 for some chars, less for others) you'll get your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you in later battles.  Even with the most pricey armour and weaponry. Tactical options are limited to finding the attacks which work best; and still you have to press Enter all the way through battle for a long time. Your only chance of taking some influence on the battles is using gear which might give extra protection against certain "elemental" enemies or... trying to escape. Which most often will not work near the end, even if your chars are maxxed. I don't know if it is even possible to win this game without cheating. I guess by poor chance it might be possible.I've played lots of RPG-Maker games and underdogs (I like to give many games a chance), but seldomly have I met something so frustrating. It is a frustration that sets in too late for you to notice to pull the plug. I know how many games require a good deal of grinding but here you do it just to see that IT DOESN'T HELP AT ALL. After you've done it.-The storyline. I don't want to put too many spoilers in here, but a good deal of it is pretty blunt. There's things never hinted or talked about by any (N)PC, it's just "BOOM - THERE IT IS - IT ALWAYS WAS LIKE THAT - TAKE THAT, SHUT UP, DO YOUR MISSION". It is extremely linear (well, many (RPG-Maker) games are to a certain degree, but here you are accompanied with this feeling right from the start. Minor Spoiler for one example: You get a world map at a certain point in the game which allows you to travel around. But you can only visit places you've already been to. Yes, sometimes there are little changes, but nothing too much.-Sidequests. They are not really quests. You can - yes, spoiler - trade in some (sometimes extremely rare) loot items for cash or experience. One by one. Always going through the same dialogue. Or you can fight some monsters which most likely will "rip you a new one" for some experience. Wow.-The Battles (again): Everything is drawn out, tons of battles are there to slow you down. Regardless of your difficulty setting you'll lose hours of your life just trying to escape or fight through the sheer number of encounters you will face. You'll spent much time restarting the game completely if you try to avoid some seemingly unnecessary fights by just reloading your game. Why? You can't flee many battles because the enemies are faster/better skilled than you. You can't just quickly restart the game with F12 because this crashes it in most instances.-Loot. How can loot be bad? Well because there often is none, instead you get additional fights which draw out the game even longer. You might have to fight even the hardest baddies to just get an empty chest or another soul-rending encounter. And often you get mediocre stuff you'd already have discarded because you need better gear to even get to the area where this stuff is located. Only money seems to help a bit.-Crashes when trying to restart with F12 (which might be a compatibility problem with Steam, I can't tell for sure), Crashes when you're trying to use some in-game items (like the great series of the "Kitt"-Books)-This is a minor complaint, but the writing and grammar... well there are noticeable errors all throughout the game.-Somebody charged money for this.I didn't even finish it yet which I wanted to accomplish before writing this review - sometimes a good ending may make up for a lot of trouble - but it is just getting slower, sluggish even, unfair to non-working, more boring and repetitive towards the end. I guess sometime I might get to it but as for now... no. Just no.There might be more to say but I feel like I've already invested too much time into this game altogether. If you ask me this is not a recommendable game. Even if you get it heavily discounted.As it is with reviews, this conclusiion might contain some subjective impressions.

												I saw the reviews and I still ended up trying the game... ugh. Lots to cover and much to agree on with others.The game description states an epic 12 hr JRPG and being a lover of RPG, I bought it via a bundle to try. Continued reading the description and yes, the plot is just like a familiar and famous ninja manga. The story plot is essentially large chunks of the ninja manga and that is just unfortunate. I feel the game could have had a much more interesting story than doing a spin-off. Next thing you notice as you start the game, is the english dialogue. This is either aimed towards a much younger crowd where the people either find cursing amusing/to be giggled at (oh my goodness, did that character just say that!) or the developers actually thought people would like such type of dialogues. My opinion: no. De-values the game and detracts from the game as well - too many errors in the dialogue. If you are even remotely a grammar nut, you will cringle throughout the game when the characters 'talk'. Next, the 'travelling' aspect of the game. There truly isn't much space to travel. The storyline is so rigid that you can't possibly deviate it, skip it, or come back to it at all. IE: you don't want to progress in the game, but want to explore the town/buy items/etc. More often than you want, you can't do it, because when you try to enter the store, your character may say 'I don't have time to do this, I have to meet ... blah'. To me, that detracts from RPGs I'm used and maybe someone likes it, but I hated it. I understand the need to progress the storyline and all, but severely limiting what a character can do in-between the plot is just aggravating to the player. Next, 'world map'. No such thing. You can't travel freely 90% of the time. Again, it's all limited depending on your progression in the story plot. Next, battle system! The game teaches you how to initiate, avoid, and fight. It's nice how they did it and through the game, I liked the battle design until a certain point. My gripe with the system is not how the battle system is made, but the balance behind the battles. Your characters learn new skills and techniques (xtu as they are called) as they level up (great stuff right? No need to find skill books or etc), their cost of using each skill or technique goes up. One skill can cost 100 and the next skill learned that is suppose to be the next level of the skill is 200. The amount of damage from the skill costing 200 does less damage than the skill that costs 100. That is ridiculous! Other similar things: 1) A skill says the ultimate skill, does 1 damage to the enemy, but a skill that you started the game with does at least 20 damage (WTF), 2) an enemy is clearly resistant to fire damage, but only to certain fire xtu - fire wall doesn't work well, but fire storm does (WTF), 3) the skill list is not organized for each character, 4) your xtu techniques doesn't get that much stronger as your character's level get stronger/you equip better weapons (IE: fireball deals 100 dmg at the beginning of the game, deals roughly the same when I maxed out the character's level with a much better equip), 5) TP reset - like mana, but they get reset out of each battle, which is aggravating because some skills need 100 TP for activation, but you have to either use an item or wait a round or two to reach 100 TP to even use it, at which point you will realize you will die before you reach 100 TP via a regular way. 6) xtu states randomly attacks 2 enemies, I use it and it ONLY attacks the enemy ONCE - the game is full of glitchs. Even aside from all those points, the most aggravating part of the game that made me stop playing (even though I bared with it all till almost the end of the game) is the balance between the enemies you fight and your character leveling up. Enemies in the game are progressive, meaning as you level up, they level up accordingly. You will notice it as you get stronger in the first part of the game. While this made me think the game is pretty cool to do it, it is broken. Once you reach your level cap - lvl 50, you will realize you are fighting eneies that are 1) higher level AND 2) above your combat statistics' capabilities (because the game was designed to have progressive enemies that will always be higher than you). IE: in a boss fight, there is the boss character and 3 henchmen. The boss character is WEAKER than the henchmen, because the henchmen follows the progressive enemy mechanism more than the boss. While you may think better equips, playing defensively, trying different strategies would work in the end, I assure you, it does not. There are items in the game where you can boost your character's stats. I bought LOADS of them to pump my characters up. The enemies just get stronger based on your stats. At this point, after the carnival part of the story plot, I am facing 4 enemies that are faster than me, deals approx an average of 1K~2K dmg per attack from each enemy, while my characters are max level, has the best equip they can get at that point in the game, exceedingly boosted, and their skills synergizes well with each other. I COULD NOT get past that battle for the longest time. I have died within 3 rounds of battle where the first round I'm attacking and the next two rounds I'm trying to survive, but fail each time. It's near impossible based on the progressive enemy mechanism. After a whole day of trying, I only got past it due to RNG - random number generator - on status afflictions. I got lucky and the enemies were stunned, paralyzed, or frozen. That was the only way I could think of to pass the battle. Which apparently, is the end of the game, because it states 'To B continued'. Yes, the game states B instead of BE.Other things: the game tries to be funny and nonchalant about breaking the 4th wall in the game. No, that just proves how lacking the game was designed. This game can't even hold up a match to Deadpool's capabilities in breaking the 4th wall. The game also limits your ability to buy certain healing items as the game progress. IE: can't buy a potion that heals 25% of max hp, but you must buy the 50% one now. Minor thing, but not cost-effective in cases where I only want to recover 25%, but I have to use a 75% potion to do it as I can't buy the other one anymore. Gaining money can also be an issue in this game. You can get loaded with gold easily if you choose to get the accessory (lucky coin) and fight/grind in the game when there are monsters to fight. However, getting the money does almost nothing, but for you to buy healing items. Getting better equips can be argued to be a pro, but NOTE, this brings difficulties with the mechanism where enemies get stronger than you consistently as you grind/equip better items. At the carnival stage, there are some awesome armor and weapons to buy, but cost a lot. I was able to afford it, but because the stats on those items are so great, my enemies are THAT much stronger as well. Overall, I played game for approx 14 hours with 4 hours of it being trying again and again to pass a battle via RNG and status afflictions. There are definitely multiple flaws in this game where I would not recommend others to play it. It's an aggravating game to play with all those flaws and even more so if you can't win a battle, because you are doing so well in the game due to the imbalanced design. If you want to play this game, you have been warned. 2/10 from me.I just noticed, I have one achievement left - reach part 2. I started on normal mode and I don't know if the hard mode is where part 2 comes in, but I am not replaying this game to find out.

												I'm rating this as negative, but really i want to give it a 5/10. Some of what's positive about this game can be found in other RPG maker games. Solid combat system, weapon/armor customization, story focus, linear gameplay. There's also a decent amount exploration for optional quests, and chests are plentiful. I can respect the effort to try and make the story themed around ninjas to get away from the generic medieval rpg maker game (though i will explain an issue with this later). It's also interesting to see the author experiment with a skill mechanic with the tp resource as i don't normally see RPG maker games use anything other than mana.Where this game looses points is in the writing. As an rpg maker game, you're writing is like %50 of the reason why people will pick up your game, so here are some notes about this games writing.-The game tries very hard to explain things very clearly, which leads to a ton of extra text that doesn't feel like it's doing anything. For example the phrase "speaking in a soft voice" wasn't necessary because the characters dialog already had gaps and stutters in it.-Thematically you're supposed to be a ninja in training, but the scenery you're in and the people you interact with aren't really themed appropriately. This is of course, an issue with making a game with RPG maker as there is a limited amount of sprites and textures provided to you, but that isn't an excuse for how jarring it is to see a knight is heavy armor in ninja academy.-The plot itself was alright, until i realized that huge chunks of it were ripped-off of young naruto's story. Finally watching anime pays off!-I never thought i'd say this, but the grammer bugged me. So many sentences just felt akward; I'm not good at mechanical writing in general so i can't explain why but half the dialog doesn't work out in my head cleanly. Normally weak writing isn't an issue for me, but for RPG's where a huge part of the investment is the story, it sucks and really drains the enjoyment out of what's supposed to be an interesting part of the game.There is also a major issue with the abilities in the game, they are incredibly unsatisfying to use. Almost none of the mana based abilities do more than you basic attack, so the only reason to use your abilities is to either deal AOE (area of effect) damage, deal a specific elemental damage, or to heal.Some minor notes: there is achievement for beating the character Zane in training, however you train with the guy twice. When you beat him the first time you don't get the achievement, which made me think the game was broken. Some clarification on that would be nice. Also i would like it if i had a chance to buy equipment with the party members i'm going to use, so i'm not having to guess what equipment they can use.Ultimately i found myself liking the game, but i suspect that's because i'm a sucker for straighforward RPG games with linear progression, not because the game was especially good. It's not to not need a walkthrough to get through the game for once. If you've played other RPG maker game you know what you're in for, maybe get it for the easy achievements but otherwise i'd avoid it.

It's okay, just know what you're getting into.3/10 Would Not RecommendFirst things first: This is not the worst game I've ever played. That being said, I can't recommend this game. The game came in a bundle with a few other games for practically pennies to the dollar, so I didn't read into the reviews before purchasing it. That was a mistake on my part. Always read the reviews.At first, I didn't know what to think of this game. For the first 10-20 minutes or so, I thought it might be a parody game, something meant to be silly. This is because although the description called the game "heavily inspired by Chrono Trigger, Final Fantasy VI, and the Dragon Quest series," the only series that it is remotely similar to is Naruto. Actually, the game reads like a confusing Naruto fanfiction: it mashes together Eastern-ish and Western themes to the point where its almost funny (your Village's Leader in the about? His name was Kage Alex) and there are a few rediculous moments in the dialouge (CHAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA-), and I think the game could have been hilarious.The battle mechanics are unbalanced and weird, and though I leveled up at an absurd rate, battles still dragged on to the point of being tedious. To be honest, I only got about 2 hours into this "12 hour RPG" and I had to put it down. The problem was that it just got so repetitive that I completely lost interest, and any investment I might have had in the plot went out the window.However, I think this game should have been what it feels like it is: A Naruto fan game. I would have enjoyed playing a Naruto RPG, even just for the novelty of it. But they dropped some really big, heavy names in the description, where the only things they have in common in this game are being pixelated turn-based RPGs.I know this game must have taken a lot of time and effort, and I would hate to see something I spent so much time and effort on be torn apart in the reviews. But my biggest problem with it is that the game's description and About were... misleading. I felt a little tricked, and no matter how little I spend on something I do not want to feel like I'd been fooled into doing it. I may pick it up later after getting a chance to digest it more, but as of right now I doubt it.

The fighting gets dull after while because the fights last seriously longer time than other jrpg games I've played. Note that english is not my native language but even with my little skill I can spot countless errors.Battle balance is even worse: both enemies and characters have very big HP and very low attack. This makes killing enemies unnecessary long and dying nearly impossible. However, 25% of battles work differently: you have even worse damage, but one spell that does big damage, but enemy - it either does genocidal damage or stunlock 3/4 of your party on first move. I am writing this review as I struggle through last battle where you have ONE character at max level, which does not have any attacks that would do significant damage (except super attack which first requires drinking skill potion - to get 100 skill points for that attack, and then actually attacking, which will not happen as you will get stunned) while enemies have elemental attacks, that end your first turn by either stunning you or paralyzing. Of course, you will be dead before you can move as you can get both paralyze and stun at the same time, but they wear out not at the same time, so you get at least one of those debuffs most of your turns.If the battle is an easy one, it will be boring. The big HP and low dmg extend battles to very long times. There is nothing else about them except that enemy lvl scales as you level up, but enemies characteristics - and that is AT LEAST agility which determines turn order and is most noticeable to this as after level up you frequently no longer attack first - grow faster. Thankfully, boss battles are of a fixed levels.For graphics and sound - PURELY default RPG maker assets. I was unable to see anything unique in this game. The only thing that was quite good is that developer used different character faces for different emotions. Not every rpg maker game does this, so it is nice too see this small feature, especially that facial expressions go very well with a plot. But the game fails in many places, so its not really helping.Plot is so-so. People say that its a Naruto ripoff, but I haven't watched that cartoon so can't say. But what I can say is that its too much absurd at times.I would not recommend buying this even with 90% discount, too much bad development choices make this game true mess. But if you like CRAZY plots - you might want to check it out, but make sure that you play on easy difficulty, as last boss is still hard as hell. People say that on hard, its unbearable right from the start of the game.

If so, this game is for you.Aside from that, it's filled with spelling errors, weird items with unclear instructions and generally it's just dull and very poorly made. 												Okay, so as someone who has tinkered with RPG Maker for years, I'm trying to cut this game a little slack, especially since it almost exclusively uses the pre-supplied resources, save for a sideview battle system and various edits of the base character graphics.I can deal with that, and I can see why it was done. However...The dialogue drives me up the wall.Several words are misspelled, punctuation seems random, and the game can't decide between "X-tu" and "xtu".Also, the obscene amount of exclamation points and question marks used is just obnoxious.And before I even get to move or look at anything, the game wants to tell me the controls, and that I can press F1 for options (including remapping the controls it just told me about) and F5 for fullscreen/window toggle.The game immediately tells you about the ninja village you live in, the Kage that sacrificed himself, the sealing of beasts inside of children, the village in the leaves, and then you go to school to meet your friends, the emo kid, the healer, and the one nobody cares about, and your first mission is to retrieve some bells from your sensei.After that, it's revealed that Orochimaru, a ninja master long thought dead, is actually alive, and is......Wait, no, sorry, I got lost there for a moment. I thought I was writing a review for a JRPG, not Naruto.You'd be forgiven for thinking they're the same thing.Also, before you see any real action, there is actually a battle tutorial.It teaches you the complex art of battle, covering topics such as "how to attack", which tells you about the attack button, and how to press it; "hp and you", which teaches you the fundamentals of health points (or sometimes hit points); "skills for the skilled", which covers everything you need to know about selecting attacks that cost MP (I think it's MP anyway, I couldn't be bothered to commit any of this to memory).But yeah, a battle tutorial. For a JRPG. Yep.And just in case you forgot, you can press F1 for options, and F5 to switch between fullscreen and windowed.There are also save points, but those don't matter, because they forgot to disable saving anywhere you want.While this game has its flaws, it still did one good thing:it taught me that I can put very little effort into an RPG Maker game, and it will make a few bucks.You too can be the next big JRPG star! ...or at least make a few bucks on some shovelware. :)

												Destiny Warriors is an epic 12 hour JRPG inspired by the greats on Super Nintendo, Sega MegaDrive (Genesis), and the Turbo Duo. Thirteen years ago, your village's leader set off to confront the spirit beasts that threatened to invade and destroy your home. Among these spirit beasts was a fire dragon that burned everything to ashes, a sea serpent with great healing abilities and a lightning bird that could attack faster than light itself. While the village leader was a powerful warrior, trained in both hand-to-hand combat and magic, he could not overpower them. Ultimately, he had no choice but to sacrifice his own life by casting a powerful sealing spell on the beasts. This trapped the beasts in the souls of three human children. Unfortunately no one in the village, including the children themselves, knew which children's souls contained the trapped spirit beasts. Thirteen years later, as you enter the village's elite warrior academy, the spirit beasts have become restless and threaten to break free from their hosts. As student after student goes missing, it's up to you and three friends to abandon your training and set out into the unknown world. Use magic, might, and cunning in order to find the missing students and defeat the spirit beasts in this amazing JRPG.

												This is a terrible turn-based RPG made with the RPG Maker engine and it's one of the worst games I've played.I can get past the limited options and visual settings that RPG Maker games suffer from, and I can get past the generic artwork and horrible music, but this game has a horrible combat system and that I can NOT get past.My main issue with this game is the fact that your enemies level up with you.This is rarely used in RPGs and with good reason. It's a horrible idea that makes no sense, and makes you want to either:1. AVOID battles at all costs to keep the enemies low level or2. Fight in the same area leveling up to 99.However, WHY would you want to skip battles in an RPG? Why would you want to repeat the same areas if you don't gain an advantage from grinding?Why do the enemies level up between battles? My team hit level 10 in the first area and the same slimes and flowers were level 10 as well. It's not like they were fighting battles, and this doesn't make sense because in the first area of the game you should not have to be fighting such high level creatures.I'm not saying this is difficult, I'm saying this is not fun and that's the most important thing.This game is garbage for this reason, and I would suggest avoiding it no matter how cheap it goes on sale.Edit: I've learned that it's possible things change later in the game, but based on this being the introduction to the game, I didn't want to continue. This is a very bad way to start off an RPG.
